utterances: A few of us, yes, it was three of us at that time.
Three of us in that group, yeah.
And I met Brandon O'Duel(ph) there a little while ago.
I was home in Dublin there a couple of...
He's in, with the RTE Irish Radio.
Well, it's great to hear from ya.
Great to talk to you and the best of luck.
Good luck for another 40, at least.
Thanks very much for the call, Patrick.
Let's try another caller, and this will be Joe, and Joe's with us from Kansas City in Missouri.
I've seen ya, followed you for years and years.
I want to say, go raibh míle maith agat (thank you, very much).
I'm kind of a mixture and, you know, I sort of developed my own style between closed and open style.
But Leo Rowsome, the king of the pipers as he was, he taught me, and he was more of an open style piper.
But as years went on, I think there's a bit of closeness came into my style of piping as well.
Well you know if you are playing the chanter, which is the melody instrument here, the open would be...
Sort of the, pippin out the notes.
And also I want to tell Matt Molloy, that, Matt, you blow James Galway's doors off.
He tongues all his notes and you play like a piper and I can hear it in everything you do.
MATT MOLLOY, (The Chieftains, Flute): Oh, thank you, very much for that.
Yeah, well no thank you and thank you again for all your years of brilliant work.
One of the questions, Paddy, about the pipes.
We think of the pipes, everybody thinks of the big, the big Scottish bagpipes, the war pipes.
In pipes and a few hundred years old; unlike the bagpipes, which we gave to the Scotts many years ago.
And look and see what they did to it.
But these ones are a little more sophisticated.
They, the chanter has two full octaves on it in comparison to, the bagpipes is compliant to the nine notes.
So this allows you to play with symphony orchestras as we do on and off and with other musicians.
So you have much more flexibility in pieces of music that you choose.
